questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy?

options.b: Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

questions.explanation:
There is an increase in the metabolism of glycogen in the vaginal epithelium during normal 
pregnancy. The changes in the vagina during pregnancy include: • Increased vascularity and hyperemia resulting in a violet/purplish color characteristic of 
Chadwick's sign • Vaginal epithelium undergoes marked proliferation (option D) with the extension of the 
squamocolumnar junction downwards • Vaginal pH decreases and becomes more acidic (option C) and varies from 3.5-6.0. • Increase in the number of Lactobacillus acidophilus (option A). It metabolizes the glycogen 
stores and causes an increased production of lactic acid. Therefore, the pH becomes acidic. • Increased volume of cervical secretion during pregnancy results in the production of thick white 
vaginal discharge.

questions.question:
Question 2: In pregnancy, vaginal cytology shows a predominance of  
.
questions.explanation: During pregnancy, vaginal cytology shows a predominance of intermediate cells.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 28-year-old woman has come for pre-conceptional counselling. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2 and 
she is worried about weight gain during pregnancy. How much weight should she gain during 
pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
The patient in the given question is obese. The recommended gestational weight gain in such a 
patient is 5-9 kg. Ideally, weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy BMI (body mass index) level. The 
gestational weight gain recommended for each BMI category by the Institute of Medicine (IOM) 
are as follows: Category 
BMI (in kg/ 
m2) Recommended weight 
gain <18.5 
12.5–18 kg Underwe 
ight Normal 
18.5–24.9 
11.5–14 kg 25–29.9 
7–11.5 kg Overweig 
ht Obese

5-9.1 kg 117 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: In pregnancy, the diaphragm is elevated by  
.
questions.explanation: The diaphragm is elevated by 4 cm in pregnancy. The anatomical changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are: • Elevation of diaphragm by 4 cm • Transverse diameter of chest increases by 2 cm • Chest circumference increases by 5-7 cm • Subcostal angle increases from 68 degrees to 103 degrees

questions.question:
Question 5: A pregnant woman at her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. 
Provided there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following would be decreased?
questions.explanation:
Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy. The changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are: (Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy) Increase 
Decrease 
Unaffected Functional residual capacityE 
xpiratory reserve volumeResi 
dual volumeTotal lung capaci 
ty Respiratory rateVital capacity 
Inspiratory reserve volume Tidal volumeInspiratory capa

ventilation

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is true about prolactin levels in pregnancy?

options.a: Lowest in pregnancy and increases after delivery
options.b: Highest at term and reduces after delivery
options.c: Increases during pregnancy and plateaus during lactation

questions.explanation:
The maternal plasma prolactin level is highest at term and reduces after delivery. Despite this 
high level, milk secretion does not occur during pregnancy due to the action of estrogen and 118 
Sold by @itachibot progesterone. Prolactin secretion returns to the nonpregnant level a few weeks after delivery. The levels of 
estrogen and progesterone fall and hence, prolactin can promote milk secretion even at a lesser 
concentration.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following produce estrogen and progesterone in the first two months of 
pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
In the first two months of pregnancy, estrogen and progesterone are produced by the corpus 
luteum. It functions maximally during the second month of pregnancy and thereafter contributes 
relatively little. Estrogen is synthesized in the placenta from the 7th week and progesterone from 
the 8th week.

questions.question:
Question 8: A pregnant woman presents to an antenatal clinic for the first time during the second 
trimester. In view of a family history of thyroid disorders, a thyroid function test is sent for. 
Altered levels of which of the following would not be a cause for concern? 111 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Total T3 levels are altered throughout pregnancy. Total T3 and total T4 increase due to stimulation of thyroid tissue by hCG during the early period 
of gestation. However, there is no change in free T3 and T4 due to an increase in thyroid-binding 
globulin (TBG). This leads to a transient fall in TSH during the early weeks of gestation. The level of TSH becomes 
normal during the second and third trimester. Hormone secretion during pregnancy: • Increased • GH • Insulin • Prolactin • Aldosterone • Testosterone • Total T3, T4 • Decreased • LH • FSH • DHEAS (dihydroepiandosterone) • Unchanged • TSH • ADH (vasopressin) 119 
Sold by @itachibot • Free T3, T4

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following do not synthesise relaxin during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Relaxin is not synthesised by the fetal adrenal gland in a pregnant woman. It is synthesised 
by corpus luteum, decidua and placenta. Relaxin is a placental protein hormone. Plasma levels peak between 8 and 12 weeks of gestation 
and decline thereafter to lower levels that persist until term. Functions of relaxin are: • Relaxation of myometrium and quiescence of early pregnancy • Enhancement of the glomerular filtration rate • Endometrial vascular remodelling by inducing secretion of VEGF

questions.question: Question 10: Which among the given features is not a major physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Among the given features hypothyroidism is not a major physiological change in pregnancy. The  -subunits of hCG and TSH are identical. An increase in hCG during pregnancy stimulates 
thyroid and leads to a decrease in TSH levels. The thyroid undergoes enlargement and boosts the 
production of hormones. This is accompanied by increased production of thyroid-binding 
globulin(TBG). All these changes increase total T4 and T3 in the first trimester. But the 
physiologically important free T4 and T3 levels remain unchanged. Hence, physiologically 
pregnant women remain euthyroid. Option A: Normal pregnancy is characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Human 
placental lactogen(hPL) secreted during pregnancy, helps in adaptation to fetal energy 
requirements. Insulin resistance causes prolonged hyperglycemia and glucose flow to the fetus. It 
also favours protein synthesis. To counterbalance the increased insulin resistance and prevent 
maternal hyperglycemia, maternal insulin levels are increased. Option B: By the 3rd trimester, there is an increase in the maternal basal metabolic rate by 10 to 
20% in comparison to a nonpregnant woman. Option D: During normal pregnancy, mean arterial pressure and vascular resistance decrease, 
while blood volume and cardiac output rate increase. This helps in meeting metabolic demands of 
the enlarged uterus, provide nutrients to rapidly growing placenta and fetus, safeguard mother 
against the effects of parturition-associated blood loss.

questions.question:
Question 11: A pregnant woman with diabetes mellitus is advised to increase her insulin dose as pregnancy 
is characterised by insulin resistance. Which of the following is not implicated in this 
phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
hCG is not implicated in insulin resistance during pregnancy. 120 
Sold by @itachibot As the fetus is dependant on maternal glucose for sustenance, the blood glucose levels are 
maintained at a high level in the mother. In response to this, the insulin level in the mother 
increases, which reduces the maternal blood glucose. To counteract this, the placenta secretes 
certain hormones which increase insulin resistance in the mother. This resistance is maximal 
between 24 to 28 weeks. Hormones increasing insulin resistance include: • Human placental lactogen - Increases lipolysis and liberation of free fatty acids • Progesterone and estrogen • Placental growth hormone - Major determinant of maternal insulin resistance after 
mid-pregnancy • Cortisol • Prolactin

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following changes are not seen in the renal system during pregnancy? 112 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Serum creatinine levels decrease during normal pregnancy from a mean of 0.7 mg/dL to 0.5 
mg/dL. Physiological changes in the renal system during pregnancy include: • Increase in: • Renal blood flow(+80%) • GFR(+50%) • Creatinine clearance • Glucosuria • Decrease in: • Plasma osmolality • Creatinine • Uric acid • Na/K/Cl Anatomical changes in the renal system during pregnancy include: • Both kidneys enlarge by 1 cm • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis - More common on the right side due to dextrorotation of the 
uterus • Congestion of the bladder causing decreased bladder capacity • Increased bladder pressure and intraurethral pressure 121 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is increased during pregnancy?

options.c: Total oxygen carrying capacity of blood

questions.explanation:
The total oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood increases during pregnancy. During pregnancy, there is an increase in total haemoglobin (Hb) resulting in increased total 
oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. However, there is a relative decrease in Hb 
concentration (hematocrit) due to a greater increase in plasma volume. This decreases 
oxygen-carrying capacity per unit volume of blood. Maternal iron stores are not sufficient to meet the increased demand during pregnancy and hence 
the serum iron and ferritin concentration falls. The plasma volume expansion also lowers serum potassium.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is a physiological change seen in pregnancy. Cardiovascular parameters that increase in pregnancy are: • Cardiac output • Stroke volume • Heart rate Cardiovascular parameters that decrease in pregnancy are: • Peripheral vascular resistance (due to smooth muscle relaxation by progesterone) • Both diastolic BP and systolic BP (decrease in DBP > SBP) • Mean arterial BP • Artery venous O2 gradient

questions.question:
Question 15: A primigravida presents in the 2nd trimester complaining that her slippers do not fit 
anymore. On examination, her pulse is 88/min and blood pressure is 130/84mm Hg. You note 
bilateral pitting edema up to the level of ankles. What would you advise her?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features are suggestive of physiological edema during pregnancy for which the most 
appropriate treatment is bed rest. It occurs due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing 
on the common iliac veins. Features of physiological edema in pregnancy are: • Slight degree of ankle edema • Usually confined to one leg, more commonly the right leg • Not associated with any other features of preeclampsia (like BP>140/90mm Hg, proteinuria) • Disappears with rest • Other cardiac, renal and hematological pathologies are absent 122 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen during pregnancy? 113 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Pulmonary blood flow is increased by 2,500 mL/min
options.b: Blood flow to the skin decreases to 300 mL/min
options.c: Blood flow to the uterus increases to 750 mL/min
options.d: Renal blood flow increases by 400 mL/min

questions.explanation:
The blood flow to the skin and mucous membranes increases during pregnancy to a maximum of 
500 mL/min by the 36th week. Symptoms experienced during pregnancy such as increased heat 
sensation, sweating or having a stuffy nose can be explained by the increased blood flow. Regional distribution of blood flow during pregnancy: • Uterine blood flow - increased from 50 mL/min in the non-pregnant state to about 750 mL near 
term. • Pulmonary blood flow - increased by 2,500 mL/min. • Renal blood flow - increases by 400 mL/min at 16th week and remains at this level till term.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 30 weeks of gestation. During 
examination, which of the following cardiovascular findings would not be a cause for alarm?
questions.explanation:
S3 is normally heard during pregnancy. The third heart sound (S3) occurs due to rapid diastolic filling in hypervolemic states such as 
pregnancy, anemia or thyrotoxicosis. Hypervolemia is a normal physiological change during 
pregnancy. The auscultation of a fixed split S2, fourth heart sound (S4) or a pericardial knock are suggestive 
of cardiac pathology.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following coagulation factors are increased in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
All clotting factors increase in pregnancy except factors XI and XIII. Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state with physiological changes such as: • All clotting factors are increased (except factors XI and XIII) • Fibrinogen levels are also increased • The viscosity of blood decreases due to hemodilution • Clotting time and bleeding time is unaffected The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational 
thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and the 
women are generally asymptomatic.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 24-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with 
complaints of dizziness on lying down for the past one week. She feels better on sitting up or 
turning to the side. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
123 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical features are suggestive of supine hypotension syndrome due to inferior vena caval 
compression. During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava 
(IVC) when the patient is in the supine position. To compensate, there will be an opening up of 
the collaterals of paravertebral and azygous veins. When collaterals fail to open, venous return of the heart is reduced leading to hypotension, 
tachycardia, and syncope. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient 
to lateral position.

questions.question:
Question 20: 114 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is true regarding the sensitivity of uterine musculature?

options.c: Enhanced by both estrogen and progesterone
options.d: Enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone

questions.explanation:
The sensitivity of uterine musculature is enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone. Estrogen stimulates the synthesis of myometrial contractile proteins through cAMP. This 
increases the excitability of uterine muscles and the frequency of action potentials. Progesterone decreases the frequency and intensity of uterine contractions. This helps to prevent 
the expulsion of the implanted ovum. However, it increases the amplitude of contraction.

questions.question: Question 21: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest her to relieve the pain?

options.c: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
options.d: Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.explanation:
Extension at the knee joint and dorsiflexion at the ankle joint helps in stretching the calf muscles 
which relieves the pain. Leg cramps are minor ailments during pregnancy mostly due to a deficiency of diffusible serum 
calcium or elevation of serum phosphorus. Management includes massaging the leg, stretching 
exercises, application of local heat, and supplementation of vitamin B1 and calcium.

questions.question: Question 22: Theca lutein cysts are not associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Theca lutein cysts are not seen in hyperprolactinemia. Theca-lutein cysts are benign ovarian lesions resulting from exaggerated physiological follicle 
stimulation. They are usually associated with markedly elevated serum levels of hCG. Theca lutein cysts are found in association with: • Large placenta • Diabetes • Anti-D alloimmunization • Multifetal gestations • Fetal hydrops • Gestational trophoblastic disease - Molar pregnancy 124 
Sold by @itachibot • Reduced hCG clearance - Chronic renal failure They may also be found in normal pregnancy due to an exaggerated response of the ovaries to 
normal circulating levels of hCG.

questions.question: Question 23: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) occurs most commonly in the third trimester or early 
postpartum period. Risk factors include Pre-eclampsia/HELLP syndrome, male fetus, previous history of AFLP, and 
multiple gestations. AFLP (acute yellow atrophy or acute fatty metamorphosis) is the most common cause of acute 
liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in 
the third trimester. It occurs due to fetal deficiency of long-chain acyl-coenzyme A 
dehydrogenase (LCHAD) or poor placental mitochondrial function. The patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice, and epigastric 
pain. Features like acute hemolysis, hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, thrombocytopenia, 
and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with 
encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death. Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. Hypofibrinogenemia, 
hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting time can be seen. An elevated d-dimer is 
seen. Microscopy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration. The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. A trial of labor by 
induction or delivery by Cesarean is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood 
transfusion should be provided. The clinical and laboratory findings of acute liver diseases in pregnancy are as follows: The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. Appropriate 
management is immediate termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestational age by induction 
or delivery by Cesarean (for obstetric reasons) is done. Intensive supportive measures including 
blood transfusion should be provided. Disorders

questions.question:
Question 24: What does the term 'placental sign' denote? 115 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: If a woman has a stillborn child, her parity decreases
options.d: Multipara is a woman who has completed 2 or more pregnancies past the period of viability

questions.explanation:
Spotting on the expected date of menstruation in the early months of pregnancy is known as 
placental sign. Cyclic bleeding may occur up to 12 weeks of pregnancy until the decidual space is obliterated by 
the fusion of decidua parietalis with decidua capsularis. The bleeding is usually scanty and lasts 
for a shorter duration than in a regular menstrual cycle. Option A: Slowing of the fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis is 
suggestive of placenta previa (especially of posterior type) and is called Stallworthy’s sign. The 
fetal heart rate recovers as soon as the pressure is released. Options C and D: Permanent lengthening of the cord and slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of 
labor are suggestive of separation of the placenta. 126 
Sold by @itachibot Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care
